MATH 545 Introduction to Time Series

Week 1

Time Series Introduction

Time series is not a series — it’s a sequence

💡 A time series is a sequence of scalar or vector-valued observations recorded at “times” $t \in T$
In this course, $T \subset R$ ( other examples: $T = \mathbb{N}, T = S^2$)

We will model time series as a realization of some stochastic process {$X_t, t\in T$}

💡 A Stochastic process {$X_t, t \in T$} is a sequence of random variables defined on a probability space ($\Omega, F, P$) and indexed by a set $T$

Examples:

  1. $X_1, …, X_n$ — i.i.d. random variables
  2. $S_n = \sum_{j=1}^n X_j, n = 1,2,3,…$ — a random walk {$S_n, n \in \mathbb{N}$}
  3. The Brownian motion {${W_t, t\in [0,1]}$}
    1. $W_0$ = 0
    2. $ orall 0 < t_1 < t_2 < … < t_k, k \ge 3$, {$w_{t_2}-w_{t_1}, w_{t_3}-w_{t_2},…, w_{t_k}-w_{t_{k-1}}$} are independent, and {$w_t - w_s$} ~ $N(0, |t-s|)$

existence —?

💡 Distribution function of $(x_{t_1}, … ,x_{t_k})$: ($k \ge 1, t_1, … t_k \in T$)
A stochastic process is characterized by its finite dimensional(fd) distribution $F_{t1, .. t_k}(x_1, … x_k) = Pr(x_{t_1} \le x_1, … x_{t_k} \le x_k)$ [高维的probability density function]
In other words it’s a distribution function(d.f.) of the random vector $(x_{t_1}, … , x_{t_k}), k \ge 1, t_1, … t_k \in T$
{$F_{t_1, … ,t_k}, k \ge 1, t_1, …, t_k \in T$} is known as a family of finite dimensional distribution of {$x_t, t\in T$}

Theorem: (A.Kolmogorov, P.J.Damell)
Assume that {$F_{t_1, … ,t_k}, k \ge 1, t_1, …, t_k \in T$} is a family of probability measure such that
(a) if $\pi$ is any permutation $\pi:{ 1, …, k} arr { 1, .. .,k}$ then $F_{t_{\pi(1)}, … t_{\pi(k)}} = F_{t_1, … ,t_k}(x_1,…,x_k)$
(b) $\lim_{x_k arr \infin} F_{t_1, … t_k}(x_1, … , x_k) = F_{t_1, … ,t_{k-1}}(x_1, …, x_{k-1})$
Then there exists a stochastic process ${ X_t, t \in T}$ that has $F$ as its f.d. distribution (finite dimensional)

Facts about Linear Algebra

let $A \in \mathbb{R}^{n imes n}$, then

  1. $A$ is symmetric if $A = A^T$(equivalently $A_{ij} = A_{ji}$ for all $i,j = 1, … ,n$)

  2. $A$ is nonnegative(positive) definite ↔ $A$ is symmetric, and $ orall x \in R^n, x e 0, \langle Ax, x angle = x^TAx \ge 0 (> 0)$

    Fact: $A$ is symmetric

    Reason: $x^TAx = \sum_{i,j=1}A_{ij}x_i x_j = x^TA^Tx$ ⇒ $x^TAx = x^T( rac{A+A^T}{2})x$ since $x^T( rac{A+A^T}{2})x = \sum_{i,j=1} x_i rac{A_{ij}+A_{ji}}{2}x_j$

    Fact: (Exercise)

    $M \in C^{n imes n}$ is self-adjoint $M = \overline M^T$ ($\overline {x+iy} = x-iy$)

    If $\langle Mx, x angle \ge 0, orall x\in C^n$ ⇒ $M$ is self-adjoint

    Lemma: show that $\langle Mx, x angle = 0, orall x \in C^n$ ⇒ $M = 0_{n imes n}$ ($M = 0$)

    not true for $M \in R^{n imes n}$: $M_{11}x_1^2+M_{22}x_2^2 +(M_{12}+M_{21})x_1x_2 = 0 orall x_1,x_2$

A is nonnegative(positive definite) ↔ A ≥ 0 (A > 0)

Properties: let $A \ge 0$ ($A \in R^{n imes n}$ be positive definite), then

  1. $A$ has n non-negative(positive) eigenvalues $\lambda_1, … ,\lambda_n$w, the corresponding eigenvectors $v_1, .. ,v_n$ form an orthonormal basis of $R^n$

    Remainder: $\lambda$ is an eigenvalue with a corresponding eigenvector v ↔ $Av = \lambda v, v e 0$

    存在一个特征根对应多个特征矩阵的情况

  2. $A$ has an eigenvalue decomposition $A = V \Lambda V^T$ where $V = (v_1, … , V_n)$ and $\Lambda$ = 只有斜角是 $\lambda_1 ,…, \lambda_n$ 的矩阵

    Alternatively, $A$ can be represented as $A = \sum_{j=1}^n \lambda_j v_j v_j^T$

    Exercise:

    1. $A \in R^{n imes n}$, $A > 0$. Then $\langle x, y angle_A = \langle Ax, y angle$ is an inner product

      $\langle x,y angle_{I_n} = \sum_{j=1}^n x_j y_j$

      $\langle x,y angle_{\Lambda} = \sum_{j=1}^n \lambda_j x_j y_j$ is an inner product ↔ $\lambda_j > 0, j = 1, … , n$

    2. the eigenvalue decomposition can be written as $A = \sum_{j=1}^n \lambda_j v_j v_j^T$

    3. let $V$ be an orthogonal matrix, then $V^T = V^{-1}$ and $V^T$ is also an orthogonal matrix

Covariance and Correlation matrices

let $Y = (Y_1 … Y_n) \in R^n$, assume that $\mathbb{E}[Y_j^2] < \infin$ for $j = 1, 2, … , n$

In that follow, $\mathbb{E}[Y] = (\mathbb{E}[Y_1] … \mathbb{E}[Y_n])$

The covariance matrix of $Y$ is defined via $\Sigma_Y = \mathbb{E}[(Y-\mathbb{E}[Y])(Y-\mathbb{E}[Y])^T] \in R^{n imes n}$

Covariance forumla: $Cov(X,Y) = E[(X-\mathbb{E}[X])(Y-\mathbb{E}[Y])]$

In particular, $(\Sigma_Y)_{ij}=\mathbb{E}[(Y_i-\mathbb{E}[Y_i])(Y_j-\mathbb{E}[Y_j])] =Cov(Y_i,Y_j)$

The correlation matrix is defined via $ ho_{i,j} = Corr(Y_i, Y_j) = rac{Cov(Y_i, Y_j)}{\sqrt{Var(Y_i)Var(Y_j)}}$ if $Var(Y_1) e 0, Var(Y_2) e 0$, else 0

In particular, the correlation matrix $R_Y$ is the covariance matrix of $( rac{Y_1}{\sqrt{Var(Y_1)}}, … , rac{Y_n}{\sqrt{Var(Y_n)}})$

Cauchy Schwarz Inequality: $|\mathbb{E}[XY]| \le \sqrt{\mathbb{E}[X^2]\mathbb{E}[Y^2]}$
⇒ this is why we need to restriction of $\mathbb{E}[Y_j^2] < \infin$ above for the deduction and definition

💡 Proposition: For any random vector $V \in R^n, \Sigma_V \ge 0$

Proof: Need to show that $x^T \Sigma_Y x \ge 0 orall x \in R$

$$
x^T \Sigma_Y x = x^T \mathbb{E}[(V-\mathbb{E}[V])(V-\mathbb{E}[V])^T]x
\ = \mathbb{E}[x^T(V-\mathbb{E}[V])(V-\mathbb{E}[V])^Tx]
\ = \mathbb{E}[\langle x, V-\mathbb{E}[V] angle^2]
\ \ge 0
$$

Proved!

Remark: $\Sigma_Y > 0$ unless the coordinates of $V$ are linearly dependent (that’s what happening when $\Sigma_Y = 0$)

Multivariate Normal Distribution

let $X$ be a r.v.

💡 Definition: Characteristic function (Fourier transformation of the density) of X is defined via $\phi_X(t) = E[e^{itx}] = E[cos(tx)] + i E[sin(tx)]$

If $X$ has pdf $p(x)$, then $\phi_x(t) = \int_R e^{itx} p(x) dx$ (Fourier transformation of the density)

Two Properties:

  1. $\phi_x(t)$ is well-defined:

    $|\phi_x(t)| = | \mathbb{E}[e^itx]| \le \mathbb{E}[e^itx] = 1$

    on a complex plane

  2. $\phi_x(t) = \phi_y(t) orall t \in R$ ↔ Distributions of $X,Y$ coincide

    characteristic function can exactly represent the distribution of a r.v. ↔ If 2 r.v. have the same characteristic function, then the 2 r.v. have exactly the same distribution

If $Y \in R^n$ is a random vector, we define $\phi_Y(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t, Y angle}], t \in R^n = \mathbb{E}[e^{i ||t||_2 \langle rac{t}{||t||_2}, Y angle}]$ — knowing distribution of all one-dimensional projections

💡 Definition: $\vec Y \in R^n$ has standard multivariate normal distribution if $Y_1, ... , Y_n$ are i.i.d. $N(0,1)$ random variables

Remark: then $\Sigma_Y = diag(1, … ,1)$ and all other are 0 matrices $=I_n$

💡 Definition: $X \in R^k$ has multivariate normal distribution if $\exist a \in R^k$ and $b \in R^{k imes n}$ such that $X = a + bY$ where $Y \in R^n$ has standard multivariate normal distribution

Properties:

  1. $\mathbb{E}[x] = a$

  2. $Cov(X) = \Sigma_X = \mathbb{E}[(X-a)(X-a)^T] = \mathbb{E}[BY(BY)^T] = \mathbb{E}[BYY^TB^T] = BB^T$

    reason for the last step: $Y$ is an orthogonal matrix (because $Y_1, … ,Y_n$ is i.i.d.)⇒ $YY^T = I_n$

    $\Sigma_X = BB^T = BQQ^TB = (BQ)(BQ)^T$ where $Q \in R^{n imes n}$ is any orthogonal matrix

⇒ Notation: $X \sim N(a, \Sigma_X)$

  1. $\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t, x angle}]$

    [Exercise] let $Y \sim N(0,1)$, then $\phi_Y(t) = e^{- rac{t^2}{2}}$

    Note that for any r.v. $Z$, the c.f. of $bZ +d$ is

    $$
    \phi_{bZ+d}(t) \= \mathbb{E}[e^{i(bZ+d)t}] \= \mathbb{E}[e^{idt+ibtZ}] \= e^{idt}\mathbb{E}[e^{ibtZ}] \=e^{idt}\phi_Z(bt)
    $$

    ⇒ $\xi \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)$, then $\phi_{\xi}(t)=e^{i\mu t}e^{- rac{t^2\sigma ^2}{2}}$ (Indeed, $ rac{\xi-\mu}{\sigma} \sim N(0,1)$, so $\xi = \sigma Z +\mu$ where $Z$ is standard normal r.v.)

Observe that $\langle t, x angle$ has normal distribution: $t^Tx = t^Ta + (t^TB)Y$ — a linear transformation of standard normal distribution

$\mathbb{E}[t^TX] = t^Ta$

$Var(t^TX) = \mathbb{E}[(t^TBY)^2] = \mathbb{E}[t^TBYY^TB^Tt] = t^TBB^Tt = t^T\Sigma_X t$ (we can drop the $\mathbb{E}$, because $t, B$ are both constant)

Characteristic Function of multivariate normal

💡 Properties of Characteristic function for single normal random variable: $X$

$\phi_X(t) = E[e^{itx}] = E[cos(tx)] + i E[sin(tx)]$

$\phi_x(t) = \int_R e^{itx} p(x) dx$

For standard normal r.v. $Y \sim N(0,1)$, $\phi_Y(t) = e^{- rac{t^2}{2}}$

For any r.v. $\xi \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)$, $\phi_{\xi}(t)=e^{i\mu t}e^{- rac{t^2\sigma ^2}{2}}$

💡 Properties of Characteristic function for multivariate normal distribution:

For random vector $X \in R^n$, $\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t, X angle}]$

For any multivariate normal variable $X \in R^n$, $\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t,x angle}] = e^{i \langle t, \mathbb{E}[x] angle - rac{\langle \Sigma_X t, t angle}{2}}$

For any multivariate normal variable $X \in R^n$, $\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t,x angle}] = e^{i \langle t, \mathbb{E}[x] angle - rac{\langle \Sigma_X t, t angle}{2}}$

Proof:

let $X = a+BY$ be multivariate normal, then

$$
\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t,x angle}]
\= \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t,a angle + i \langle t, bY angle}]
\= e^{i \langle t,a angle}\mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t, BY angle}]
\ = e^{i \langle t,a angle}\mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle B^Tt, Y angle}]
$$

For $\langle B^Tt, Y angle ,$$\langle B^Tt, Y angle = \sum_{j=1}^n (B^Tt)_j Y_j$ ⇒ normal distribution

Since any linear combination of independent normal r.v. is still normal (can be proved using characteristic function)

Therefore, $\mathbb{E}[ \langle B^Tt, Y angle] = 0$ and $Var(\langle B^Tt, Y angle) = ||B^Tt||_2^2$ (since sum of variance = variance of sum and $Var((B^Tt)_j Y_j) = (B^Tt_j)^2 Var(Y_j) = (B^Tt_j)^2$)

⇒ $\langle B^Tt, Y angle \sim N(0, ||B^Tt||_2^2)$ which can be regard as $||B^Tt||_2Y$ where $Y$ is a standard random variable

⇒ $\mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle B^T t, Y angle}] = \mathbb{E}[e^{i(t^TB)Y}]= e^{- rac{||B^Tt||_2^2}{2}}$

Since $||B^Tt||_2^2 = \langle B^Tt, B^Tt angle = \langle t, BB^Tt angle = \langle t, \Sigma_x t angle = \langle \Sigma_x t, t angle$,

$\mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle B^T t, Y angle}] = e^{- rac{||B^Tt||_2^2}{2}} = e^{- rac{\langle \Sigma_X t, t angle}{2}}$

Therefore, the final characteristic function of a multivariate normal distribution is $\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t,x angle}] = e^{i \langle t, \mathbb{E}[x] angle - rac{\langle \Sigma_X t, t angle}{2}}$

💡 Proposition:

$X = (X_1, …, X_k)$ has multivariate normal distribution $\sim N(a, \Sigma_X)$

↔  $ orall Z = (Z_1, … ,Z_k) \in R^k$, $\langle Z, X angle \sim N(Z^Ta, Z^T \Sigma_x Z)$

Proof:

  1. forward direction:

    $X \sim N(a, \Sigma_X)$ means that $X = a + BY$ where $BB^T=\Sigma_X$ and $Y$ is a vector of i.i.d. standard r.v.s

    $Z^TX = Z^T(a+BY) = Z^Ta + Z^TBY$, which is a linear combination of independent normal distributions, so it must be normal distributions

    or can be regard as a linear transformation of $Y$

    $E[Z^TX] = Z^Ta$

    $Var(Z^TX) = (Z^TB)(Z^TB)^T = Z^TBB^TZ = Z^T \Sigma_XZ$

    ⇒ $\langle Z, X angle \sim N(Z^Ta, Z^T \Sigma_x Z)$

  2. backward direction:

    Assume that $\langle Z, X angle \sim N(Z^Ta, Z^T \Sigma_x Z) orall Z\in R^k, Z e 0$

    use the characteristic function of multivariate normal distribution: $\phi_X(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i \langle t,x angle}] = e^{i \langle t, \mathbb{E}[x] angle - rac{\langle \Sigma_X t, t angle}{2}}$

    c.f. of $Z^TX$ is $\phi_{Z^TX}(t) = \mathbb{E}[e^{i(Z^TX)t}] = e^{iZ^Tat} e^{- rac{t^2Z^T\Sigma_XZ}{2}}$

    take $t=1$ ⇒ $\mathbb{E}[e^{i(Z^Tx)}] = e^{i(Z^Ta)} e^{- rac{Z^T\Sigma_X Z}{2}}$ matches the c.f. of multivariate normal distribution

Example of p.d.f. DNE (that’s when we can only use characteristic function)

Question: $X = a +BY$, $a \in R^k$, $B \in R^{k imes m}$, $Y \sim N (0,1)$. What if $rank(B) < k$?

Remainder: rank = # of max linearly independent columns

Note that $\Sigma_X = BB^T$

⇒ $det(\Sigma_x) = 0$

↔$\exist Y \in R^k$ s.t. $\Sigma_X Y =0$

⇒ $Var(Y^TX)= Y^T\Sigma_X Y = 0$

⇒ $Y^TX = Y^Ta$ ($a$ is some constant vector)

⇒ coordinates of $X$ are linearly dependent

($rank(B) < k \lrarr x$ “lives” in a subspace of $R^k$ = $X$ does not have a p.d.f.)

Case k=2, $rank(B)=1$:

$X=(x_1,x_2) \in R^2$, then $X$ belong to some line $ax+by+c$ in this plane

$X$ does not have a p.d.f. in this case

Proof:

Assume that p.d.f. $p_x$ exists. WLOG, assume that $p_x$ is bounded

Pick some area $R$ s.t. $Pr(x\in R) > 0$

$Pr(x\in R) = \int_R Pr(x) dx \le \sup_{x \in R} Pr(x) imes volume(R)$

assume $Area(R) = r_1 imes r_2$

$Pr(x \in R)$ must be the same $ orall r_2$

but if $r_2 arr 0, \sup_{x\in R} Pr(x) imes volume(R) arr 0$

$\lrarr Pr(x \in R) arr 0$

⇒ $Pr(x \in R)$ does not exists

⇒ contradiction

⇒ $P_x$ does not exist

example for p.d.f. does not exist:

$X \sim N(0,1)$, let a vector be $(X, 1)$ ⇒ there is density on the line, but no density in the 2D space

Deriving pdf of a full-rank random vector

Now assume that $rank(B) = k$ (in particular, imply $m \ge k$, $B \in R^{k imes m}$)

Let us derive the p.d.f. of $X$

Remainder:

let $Z \in R^k$ be a random vector with p.d.f. $P_Z$, assume that $Z = g(x)$ for some one-on-one function $g$, what is the p.d.f. of X?

$Pr(Z \in A) = \int_A P_Z(z) dz$

⇒ $Pr(x \in g^{-1}(A)) = \int_{g^{-1}(A)}P_Z(g(x)) |D_{g(x)}|dx$, where $|D_{g(x)}|$ is the Jacobian matrix of $g(x)$

⇒ p.d.f. of x (represented by $g(x)$) is: $P_Z(g(x)) |D_{g(x)}|$

we need to further derive a closed form for this equation

Step 1: Take $Z \in R^k$ to be standard normal

$Z = (Z_1, … Z_k)$, $Z_1, … ,Z_k$ be independent $N(0,1)$

⇒ $P_Z(Z_1, …, Z_k) = P(Z_1) … P(Z_k), P(Z_i) = rac{1}{\sqrt {2\pi}}e^{- rac{z^2}{2}}$

⇒ $P_Z(Z_1, … , Z_k) = rac{1}{(\sqrt{2\pi})^k}e^{-\sum_{i}^k rac{z_i^2}{2}} = rac{1}{(\sqrt{2\pi})^k}e^{- rac{||z||_2^2}{2}}$

Step2: Define $X \sim N(0, \Sigma_X), \Sigma_X > 0$ (normalize $X$)

Note that $\Sigma_X = U \Lambda U^{T}$ where $U$ is a matrix whose columns are eigenvectors and $\Lambda = diag(\lambda_1, … ,\lambda_k)$

To normalize $X$, define $Z = \Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}U^TX$ ($Z$ is a multivariate normal since it is a linear combination of multivariate normal)

$E[Z] = 0$

$\Sigma_Z = E[ZZ^T] = E[\Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}U^TX X^T U \Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}] = \Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}U^T E[XX^T]U \Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}} = \Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}U^T U\Lambda U^TU \Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}$

since $U^TU = I$ (as $U$ is orthogonal matrix), $\Sigma_Z = I$

⇒ $Z \sim N(0,I_k)$ in this case

⇒ $P_X(X_1, …,X_K) = rac{1}{(2\pi)^{ rac{k}{2}}}\exp(-||\Lambda^{- rac{1}{2}}U^TX||_2^2 X||)$ and what I can’t understand whats on the blackboard

Chapter 2 Hilbert Space (not updated yet)

Definition: A pre-Hilbert space is a vector space equipped with an inner product $\langle \cdot ; , ; \cdot angle: \mathbb{H} imes \mathbb{H} arr \mathbb{C} $ that satisfies:

  1. $\langle x ; , ; y angle = \overline{ \langle y ; , ; x angle}$

  2. $ \langle \alpha x ; , ; y angle = \alpha \langle x ; , ; y angle$

  3. $ \langle x+y ; , ; z angle = \langle x ; , ; z angle + \langle y ; , ; z angle$

  4. $\langle x ; , ; x angle \ge 0 $ and $\langle x ; , ; z angle = 0 \iff x = 0 $
